body: ''CONTRARY to what's been believed in the area of psychotherapy,'' said Irving M. Levine, ''cultural factors are tremendously important, and cultural differences maintain themselves sometimes into the fourth and fifth generations. Highly assimilated WASP's and Jews are not going to be as alike in behavior patterns and belief systems as has been
title: LONG ISLANDERS; ON BEING PART OF A MIXED SOCIETY

body: After years of negotiation, a final division of the four boroughs outside Manhattan among six cable television companies was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Officials said service could be brought into some homes as early as June. ''In Staten Island,'' said Morris Tarshis, director of franchises, ''it could come like that'' and he
title: DELAYED YEARS, CABLE TV TO EXPAND TO ALL OF CITY

body: WATER DANCER By Jenifer Levin. 368 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95. MATTERS OF CHANCE By Gail Albert. 254 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95. title: SWIMMING AND SURVIVING

body: A Brooklyn youth was shot to death early yesterday morning in Times Square, and the police said they had a photograph, taken only minutes before the shooting, of a man who might be the killer. The victim, 19-year-old Dion Williamson of 350 Blake Avenue in the Brownsville section, was shot once in the head at 3:20 A.M. in front of 1 Times Square
title: Brooklyn Youth Is Slain In a Times Sq. Dispute

body: During a recent meeting of 100 Black Men, a citywide civic and social group of blacks from business, government, academia and politics, the subject of Brooklyn politics arose. Some suggested that the Nov. 2 elections confirmed a shift in black political power in the city from Manhattan to Brooklyn. Though there was no consensus on that, there was
title: BLACK POLITICIANS SAVOR NEW STRENGTH

body: And These Little Piggies Went to the A.S.P.C.A. I t was going to be some Thanksgiving barbecue. The five children - ''and the grands'' - of John and Lenora Holmes would gather at the Van Dyke Houses in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. Mr. Holmes, a former North Carolina butcher, would serve up the three middle-sized pigs he has been
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Thinking about it still gives them both a chill. And though it has been a year, and they've been over it hundreds of times, they still like telling the story - every glorious detail - of when and how they found out they had won $5 million in the New York State Lottery. Since then, they have traveled to Hawaii, California and Las Vegas, Nev. They
title: A YEAR LATER, LOTTERY PRIZE STILL A 'FANTASY'

body: MATTERS OF CHANCE. By Gail Albert. 254 pages. Putnam. $14.95. MY OLD SWEETHEART. By Susanna Moore. 211 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $12.95. title: Books Of The Times

body: Almost 4,000 jobs have been created or saved in New York City by an 18-month-old Consolidated Edison Company program that offers reduced electricity rates to commercial customers who agree to expand or relocate in depressed neighborhoods, according to the city and the utility. More than 1,000 businesses in the South Bronx and parts of Brooklyn have
title: CON ED RATES PROGRAM CLAIMS PROGRESS ON JOBS

body: Rebuilding in Brownsville I n a Brownsville area of vacant lots lots and abandoned walkups, people from 40 Brooklyn congregations gathered yesterday at the groundbreaking for the Nehemiah Plan - the East Brooklyn Churches coalition's projected 21 square blocks of single-family row houses, named for the biblical figure who rebuilt Jerusalem. With
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: A 42-year-old off-duty police officer was fatally shot early yesterday on a Brooklyn street after he intervened in a dispute between a man and a woman, the police said. The officer, James Whittington, was shot three times a few minutes after midnight in front of 340 Dumont Avenue in the Brownsville section, said John Clifford, a spokesman for the
title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER SLAIN IN BROOKLYN

body: An off-duty police officer was shot to death in Brooklyn early this morning, the police said. The officer, who was not immediately identified, was found at 12:07 A.M. in front of a housing project at 330 Dumont Street in the Brownsville section. He was taken to Brookdale Hospital with a chest wound and died there at 1:20 A.M., according to Peter
title: THE CITY; Off-Duty Officer Slain in Brooklyn

body: New York City officials said yesterday that they had arranged to underwrite the construction of 435 single-family homes for low- and moderate-income families in three rundown Brooklyn neighborhoods by combining Federal funds with loans from city pension funds. Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who is a pension-fund trustee, said he thought it was the
title: CITY UNDERWRITES PROJECT FOR 435 BROOKLYN HOUSES

body: Harold U. Ribalow, author and editor of some 15 books, most of them dealing with Jewish themes, died of cancer last Friday at his home in New York City. He was 63 years old. Mr. Ribalow worked for 30 years for the Israel Bond Organization in New York and he held a variety of other writing and editing positions. They included editor of the
title: HAROLD U. RIBALOW, WRITER ON JEWISH THEMES

body: Voluntary agencies and community groups all over New York City report marked increases in people who say they have no money for food. In poor neighborhoods and in relatively affluent ones, adults and children are lining up in growing numbers for bags of groceries or for hot meals ladled out at soup kitchens, according to officials for the groups.
title: HUNGER FOUND TO GRIP RISING NUMBER IN CITY

body: A judge yesterday ordered a rerun next Tuesday of two disputed Democratic primary races in Brooklyn - one for the House of Representatives and one for the State Assembly - after charges of voting fraud. The order for the two reruns, which was given by Acting Justice Eugene Berkowitz of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, threw out the Sept. 23
title: RERUNS ORDERED IN BROOKLYN FOR TWO DISPUTED ELECTIONS

body: A 41-year-old Brooklyn man was killed yesterday by two United States deputy marshals after he wounded one of them with submachinegun fire, authorities said. The marshals were seeking to arrest him at his home for a Federal parole violation. The injured marshal suffered a superficial head wound. The dead man was identified as Clyde Evans of 982
title: Federal Marshals Kill Armed Brooklyn Man

body: THOUGH it's his latest cartoon feature to arrive in New York, Ralph Bakshi's ''Hey Good Lookin' '' is not exactly his newest, having been ''in work'' since 1975. Between the start of production and the film's completion, this most innovative and audacious of contempory animated film makers has produced ''Wizards'' (1977), ''The Lord of the Rings''
title: BAKSHI'S 'GOOD LOOKIN'

body: Two former state senators with different political styles and backed by rival black political factions in central Brooklyn will face each other in next week's Democratic primary. The contest for the newly drawn 12th District resulted from the decision by Representative Shirley Chisholm not to seek re-election. The outcome is likely to determine not
title: 2 EX-STATE SENATORS VIE FOR REP. CHISHOLM'S JOB

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: Lunch for a Cause I n Brooklyn's Fort Greene section this morning, at least 100 business and professional people know exactly where their next meal is coming from: Lunchtime will bring a chicken dinner, delivered for $3 by some other people mobilizing for a voice in where their next housing is coming from. Cooking started last night at the
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: When an ecumenical coalition of 36 churches asked the city last month to help it build 5,000 single-family town houses in the Ocean Hill, Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn, the Koch administration was respectfully - but deeply - skeptical. Respectful, because the four-year-old coalition, known as East Brooklyn Churches, has worked
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; BROOKLYN CHURCHES GAIN CITY HELP FOR NEW HOMES

body: The Koch administration has agreed to lend $10 million to a coalition of 36 Brooklyn churches that plans to build 5,000 singlefamily town houses in blighted sections of Brooklyn. The $10 million will be given as a direct loan of $10,000 to each buyer of the first 1,000 homes the coalition, East Brooklyn Churches, will build on the vacant parcels of
title: CITY AGREES TO BROOKLYN HOME LOANS

body: For an executive who founded a company and nurtured it for about 30 years, the idea of retiring and selling a controlling interest to another company can be a difficult prospect. But Benjamin Osher has managed to avoid the problems of keeping the stock in the family and the temptation to tell his successors how to run the business. Mr. Osher, who
title: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Kleer-Vu's Founder Prepares to Step Down

body: Eight Russian immigrants were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of selling drugs and firearms, the police said. Those arrested, in a series of raids by the department's narcotics division and the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, were said to be part of an operation that imported and sold cocaine, heroin and weapons. ... A
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: A coalition of 36 Brooklyn churches announced plans yesterday to build 5,000 single-family town houses in blighted sections of Ocean Hill, Brownsville and East New York. The three areas are among several in Brooklyn that have experienced severe housing abandonment and devastation in the last decade. Beginning next March, the group, East Brooklyn
title: 36 CHURCHES IN BROOKLYN PLAN TO BUILD 5,000 HOMES

body: International A face-saving offer to the P.L.O. was announced by Prime Minister Menachem Begin in an address to the Israeli Parliament. Declaring that Israel had no desire to humiliate the Palestinian guerrillas, he said they could leave Beirut with their personal weapons. Just two days earlier, Israel's Cabinet insisted that the arms be
title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 30, 1982

body: The improved achievement of students in the New York City public schools, which showed up last year in scores on reading tests, took on added significance this year when scores on mathematics tests rose, as well. Test results made available last week by the Board of Education showed that the number of students scoring above the national norms
title: CITY STUDENTS RAISE SCORES IN NATIONAL MATH TESTS

body: For the first time in at least a decade, students in the New York City public schools exceeded the national averages in both reading and mathematics scores, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the city's Board of Education. Results of tests given in April show that 51 percent of the students tested in reading and 56.5 percent in
title: STUDENTS IN CITY TOP U.S. LEVELS FOR SCHOOL TESTS

body: A 52-year-old woman was arrested and charged with drowning her 3-year-old foster son, whose body was found by the police shortly after 5:30 P.M. in the bathtub of the woman's apartment at 3609 Broadway in uppper Manhattan. The police identified the woman as Rosemarie Lewis and the boy as Gerard Jones.... A Brooklyn teen-ager was shot by two police
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: ON April 27, Rebecca Taylor, acting principal of Intermediate School 44 on Manhattan's Upper West Side, was notified that she had been denied tenure. Ordinarily, such an administrative decision attracts little attention. But little is ordinary about the school at 77th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues and the community it serves. The
title: ABOUT EDUCATION

body: A 9-year-old Brooklyn boy who had been missing since Saturday afternoon was found dead of head injuries yesterday morning, the police said. The boy, Paris Turner of Riverdale Avenue in the Brownsville section, was found at 9:15 A.M. in an abandoned building at 536 Junius Street, a short distance from the playground where he was last seen at 2 P.M.
title: Brooklyn Boy, 9, Found Slain

body: Federal budget cuts in child-care programs have forced public daycare centers in New York City to serve one less meal and snack a day, lower their nutritional standards and raise their fees, according to city officials and day-care administrators. ''The most devastating thing is that this happens when New York day care is needed most,'' said
title: U.S. CUTS LIMITING DAY CARE FOR POOR

body: A few weeks ago, 19-year-old Larry Carson was seized by a Transit Authority police officer as he vaulted over a subway turnstile at a station near his Brooklyn home. Yesterday, he and 19 other young fare-beaters and vandals paid for their crimes by removing graffiti from subway car walls. ''I guess you could say we're making our mark in society
title: FIRST VIOLATORS TO CLEAN SUBWAY CARS GET TO WORK

body: A 5-year-old boy was killed yesterday when he was struck by a hitand-run driver near his home in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, the police said. The boy, identified as Rashawn Johnson, of 1894 Pacific Street, was struck in front of 1917 Pacific Street at 6:10 P.M, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Leroy Barr. The boy was pronounced dead at St.
title: THE CITY; Hit-and-Run Auto Kills Brooklyn Boy

body: A supermarket in the South Bronx paid a $4,365 electricity bill last month. It might have paid $5,573, had it not been for a rate reduction of almost 22 percent from Consolidated Edison. A small doll factory in Brooklyn paid $174 instead of the $218 it would normally have been billed, and a Bronx plastics manufacturer whose February electricity
title: CON ED'S DISCOUNTS HELP GENERATE NEW JOBS

body: In Rochester and some of its suburbs, a political campaign is under way that Democrats hope will strengthen their party's position in the State Senate. The race, for the seat in the 54th Senate District that had been held by Fred J. Eckert, a Republican who quit to become United States Ambassador to the Fiji Islands, is one of five that will be
title: DEMOCRATS HOPING FOR GAINS IN SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE VOTING

body: A federally financed nutrition program designed to help poor families in New York City learn to maintain a healthy diet has been spending less time counting vitamins and more time budgeting grocery money since cuts were made in the food stamp program. ''We still do nutrition, but we are stressing a lot more stretching of dollars because that's
title: NUTRITION PROJECT URGES ECONOMIZING

body: Burned out of their homes by arsonists or frozen out by negligent landlords, more than 700 homeless families are getting temporary shelter from the city in a handful of hotels and rehabilitated apartment houses. While no homeless families have been turned away, city officials say they are distressed that the shelters are nearly full, mainly because
title: CITY TEMPORARILY SHELTERING OVER 700 HOMELESS FAMILIES

body: Four months after the slayings of a Brink's guard and two policemen in an armored-car robbery in Rockland County, a complex story has begun to emerge of a subterranean culture sustained by a small network of people who view themselves as warriors in a global revolution. It is a group of single-minded people leading double lives, often under
title: BEHIND THE BRINK'S CASE: RETURN OF THE RADICAL LEFT

body: Reacting to the death on the street last month of a homeless woman, the city is moving more quickly to get court permission to forcibly hospitalize people in immediate physical danger who refuse help. The dead woman was 60-year-old Rebecca Smith, who froze to death in a cardboard hut on 10th Avenue and 17th Street 10 days after her situation was
title: CITY STEPS UP COURT ACTIONTO AID HOMELESS AND OTHERS

body: The CC train is the longest line in the New York City subway system, running 32.39 miles from Bedford Park in the Bronx to the Rockaway Peninsula, and passing through -or, in most cases, beneath - a number of the city's best-known neighborhoods and landmarks. The line runs through four of the boroughs, missing only Staten Island, and it operates
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; THE CC RATTLES ALONG AN UNLIKELY PATH
